title: 12 Years a Slave
description: A formerly free man is kidnapped and sold as a slave in the 1840s American South in this searing drama; winner of multiple Oscars.
starring: Chiwetel Ejiorfor, Lupita Nyong'o, Benedict Cumberbatch, Steve McQueen

title: All Is Lost
description: J.C. Chandor's film features a solo sailor and almost no dialogue; it’s ultimately less about a nautical crisis than a man gradually realizing, in every sense of the word, that he is lost.

title: Amour
description: A long-married French couple faces illness together in a story that's wrenchingly sad, but not without joy.

title: Before Midnight
description: The final film in Richard Linklater's romantic trilogy; it's is often uncomfortable to watch, it’s never less than mesmerizing — and ultimately, a joy to walk with the prickly but fascinating Jesse and Celine again.
starring: Richard Linklater, Ethan Hawke, Julie Delpy

title: Blue Jasmine
description: It's Woody Allen, but this is no comedy -- Cate Blanchett shines in a wrenching portrait of a woman whose life has fallen apart.

title: The Broken Circle Breakdown
description: This gentle tale of a bluegrass-loving Belgian couple unapologetically explores melodrama; these characters experience big, dramatic emotions, and the movie rides on those waves.

title: Captain Phillips
description: Tom Hanks, in one of his career's finest performances, plays the captain of a container ship hijacked by Somali pirates; the film feels utterly real and almost unbearably intense.

title: The East
description: Brit Marling gives a remarkable, thoughtful performance as a corporate spy sent to infiltrate a group of ecoterrorists.

title: Fruitvale Station
description: Director Ryan Coogler's depiction of a real-life police shooting in 2009 is an eloquent memorial for a young man (Michael B. Jordan) who barely experienced life.

title: Her
description: A man (Joaquin Phoenix) falls in love with the voice of an operating system in Spike Jonze's unique rom-com.
starring: Spike Jonze, Joaquin Phoenix, Scarlett Johansson

title: The Hunt
description: This gripping Danish drama, starring Mads Mikkelson, is the story of  a lie, and how that lie changed a man and a town.

title: In the House
description: French filmmaker Francois Ozon crafts an intriguing story about storytelling: about what happens when an English teacher gets lost inside a life that isn't his.
starring: Francois Ozon, Kristin Scott Thomas, Fabrice Luchini

title: Inside Llewyn Davis
description: From the Coen brothers -- a splendid, touching, darkly comic film about a 1960s Greenwich Village folk singer (Oscar Isaac) at a crossroads.
starring: Joel Coen, Ethan Coen, Oscar Isaacs, Carey Mulligan

title: Nebraska
description: Alexander Payne's wonderful not-quite-comedy/not-quite-drama is the story of a father and a son, and of how they come to understand each other, just a bit, on a Midwest road trip.
starring: Bruce Dern, Will Forte, Alexander Payne, Bob Nelson

title: Philomena
description: An utterly charming combination of road-trip movie, odd-couple comedy and heart-touching true story that will leave few dry-eyed, this film stars the great Judi Dench as an elderly woman searching for her son.
starring: Judi Dench, Steve Coogan, Stephen Frears

title: Prisoners
description: Hugh Jackman plays a desperate father searching for his kidnapped daughter in this dark examination of how loss can unhinge us.
starring: Hugh Jackman, Jake Gyllenhaal, Viola Davis, Denis Villeneuve

title: Rust and Bone
description: This French-language drama reminds us that not everything broken can be fully mended — and that Marion Cotillard, as a character both steely and fragile, is one of the most mesmerizing actresses currently on screen.

title: The Spectacular Now
description: James Ponsoldt’s “The Spectacular Now,” based on the Tim Thorp novel, hits on something few movies do: an honest, believable depiction of teenagers, in love and out.

title: Still Mine
description: Bring a handkerchief, or possibly a bedsheet, to “Still Mine”; this fact-based, beautifully acted drama about an elderly Canadian couple could wring tears from a brick.

title: What Maisie Knew
description: Based on a Henry James story, this beautifully acted contemporary tale of a divorcing couple has a child at its center -- whom both parents use as a weapon.

title: Zero Dark Thirty
description: This harrowing military drama from director Kathryn Bigelow, about the capture and death of Osama bin Laden, isn’t easy viewing — but just try to look away.

title: American Hustle
description: Told in a whoosh of nylon shirts, yellowy light and disco music. David O. Russell’s film is the sort-of-based-on-fact story of the 1970s Abscam scandal, in which a con man and the FBI join forces.
starring: Amy Adams, Jennifer Lawrence, Bradley Cooper, Jeremy Renner, David O. Russell

title: Enough Said
description:
A smart, funny, snappy romantic comedy for grown-ups, Nicole Holofcener’s film is a joy, marred only by the poignancy of seeing the late 
James Gandolfini (opposite a wonderful Julia Louis-Dreyfus) in one of his final screen appearances.
starring: Julia Louis-Dreyfus, James Gandolfini, Nicole Holofcener

title: Much Ado About Nothing
description: Filmed in elegant black-and-white, with the cast in contemporary dress, Joss Whedon's updated take on Shakespeare is a merry, occasionally dark romp.

title: The Way, Way Back
description: Much of Nat Faxon and Jim Rash’s summer-breeze comedy Back” feels familiar, but in a good way, like a comfortably rumpled beach house you’re happy to return to year after year.
starring: Toni Collette, Steve Carell, Allison Janney, Nat Faxon, Jim Rash, Sam Rockwell

title: 56 Up
description: The latest installment in Michael Apted's fascinating, landmark documentary series checks in on a group of Brits every 7 years; they're now settling comfortably into middle age.

title: The Act of Killing
description: A horrifying yet mesmerizing work, Joshua Oppenheimer's documentary examines the history of Indonesian genocide.

title: At Berkeley
description: Filmed at the University of California at Berkeley during the fall semester of 2010, Frederick Wiseman's documentary depicts -- in small dabs -- a vibrant, buzzing universe.

title: Cutie and the Boxer
description: This documentary tale of two long-married Brooklyn artists (whose cluttered loft seems encrusted with possessions) is told with style and wit.

title: Deceptive Practices: The Mysteries and Mentors of Ricky Jay
description: In this irresistible documentary, the viewer is introduced to Ricky Jay, one of the world's foremost sleight-of-hand artists.

title: Dirty Wars
description: In this powerful, scary documentary, two filmmakers get to know an Afghan family profoundly affected by a secret American government operation, carried out with drones.

title: Good Ol' Freda
description: The longtime secretary to the Beatles, now a grandmother, tells her story in this delightful documentary.

title: Muscle Shoals
description: One of the best music documentaries ever made, this utterly compelling film tells the story of a tiny, legendary recording studio in Alabama.

title: Stories We Tell
description: Past and present merge, in an continual and still-emerging story, as filmmaker Sarah Polley examines a long-held family secret.

title: Wagner & Me
description: Stephen Fry examines his complex feelings toward Wagner and his music - and part of the pleasure of this film is seeing how the composer's art transforms him.

title: The Waiting Room
description: This documentary, taking place over 24 hours in the emergency room of Oakland’s  public Highland Hospital, emerges as a moving portrait of people doing their jobs -- and doing them well -- under very difficult circumstances.

title: We Steal Secrets: The Story of Wikileaks
description: Alex Gibney’s thoughtful, well-researched documentary about the Julian Assange/WikiLeaks saga explores a complex moral problem: When does a whistle-blower become a traitor?

title: The Conjuring
description: James Wan’s haunted-house saga is well-crafted, convincingly acted, surprisingly restrained and scary as hell.
starring: Vera Farmiga, Patrick Wilson, Ron Livingston, James Wan

title: The Invisible Woman
description: An elegantly told tale of a secret love affair, between author Charles Dickens (Ralph Fiennes) and his much-younger mistress, Nelly Ternan (Felicity Jones).

title: Like Father, Like Son
description: A gentle, nuanced drama from Japan, in which two families cope with the news that their six-year-old sons were switched at birth.

title: Tim's Vermeer
description: This whimsical documentary is about many things — art history, technology, painting technique, beauty — but ultimately it’s a beguiling study of fascination, as an inventor attempts to re-create a famous Vermeer painting.

title: The Grand Budapest Hotel
description: The title character of Wes Anderson's enchanting film is an art-deco dream gone to seed. It’s the quiet hero of a story that takes place in three different time periods; a trio of tales like a set of tables, each fitting under the other.
starring: Wes Anderson, Ralph Fiennes, Tilda Swinton, Tom Wilkinson, Saoirse Ronan, Jude Law

title: A Birder's Guide to Everything
description: Like a less-quirky cousin of Wes Anderson's "Rushmore," this sweet coming-of-age tale is about a young man burying himself in activities in an attempt to escape the pain of loss.

title: Captain America: The Winter Soldier
description: The title superhero's struggle to survive in a universe where conventional morality no longer holds sway gives this film a significantly higher quotient of substance than is usually found in a comic-book adaptation.
starring: Chris Evans, Samuel L. Jackson, Scarlett Johansson, Robert Redford

title: Under the Skin
description: You won’t easily shake off this strange, night-blooming science-fiction tale about a beautiful woman (Scarlett Johansson) who isn’t a woman at all.

title: Finding Vivian Maier
description: An engaging unravelling of a real-life mystery: the photographs left behind by a Chicago street photographer.

title: Locke
description: Steven Knight’s tight little drama is, without question, a stunt --it takes place almost entirely in the front seat of a BMW, during a late-night drive from Birmingham to London -- and, for the most part, it works like gangbusters.

title: Belle
description: This period drama about a mixed-race young heiress in 18th-century England is an old-fashioned movie with a very modern streak, centered by a vibrant star turn by Gugu Mbatha-Raw.
starring: Gugu Mbatha-Raw, Tom Wilkinson, Amma Asante

title: How to Train Your Dragon 2
description:
The plot for this family-friendly sequel doesn’t matter in the slightest; young and old fans of the first movie will be lining up for the wit, for the inventiveness of the characters, for the breathtaking visuals — and just the sheer fun of it. 
all

title: Life Itself
description: You don’t have to be a movie critic, or even particularly interested in movies, to be touched and enthralled by this documentary about Roger Ebert; it's a beautifully paced tribute to a life well-lived.

title: Violette
description: This impressionist biopic about French novelist Violette Leduc (Emmanuelle Devos) unfolds like a novel; divided into numbered and titled chapters and adding up to a satisfying whole.

title: Boyhood
description: Richard Linklater's award-winning drama, 12 years in the making, eloquently follows a young man's coming of age.
starring: Richard Linklater, Ethan Hawke, Patricia Arquette

title: Guardians of the Galaxy
description: Whiz-bang, damn-the-torpedoes, high-octane good times roll in this superhero romp, in which five "guardians" (including a talking raccoon) band together to save the galaxy.
starring: Chris Pratt, Vin Diesel, Zoe Saldana

title: Get On Up
description: Tate Taylor’s new film biography of James Brown, aka the Godfather of Soul, is unexpectedly buoyant; it skims over a life as if tunefully improvising, touching just the right note here and there.
starring: Chadwick Boseman, Viola Davis, Octavia Spencer, Tate Taylor

title: Mood Indigo
description: Watching this whimsical French love story, you marvel at how no one makes movies quite like Michel Gondry (“Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind,” “Human Nature”) — and at how a dash of curlicued surrealism somehow makes the real world, in all its staidness, a happier  place.

title: Calvary
description: This Irish drama unfolds as a murder mystery in reverse, serving as a marvelous showcase for Brendan Gleeson -- a great old-lion actor with a face on which emotions play like waves on the beach.

title: Love Is Strange
description: Ira Sachs' gentle love story features John Lithgow and Alfred Molina as a longtime couple who must separate due to real-estate troubles; the actors movingly depict the kind of partnership in whihc neither is complete without the other.
starring: John Lithgow, Alfred Molina, Ira Sachs

title: Gone Girl
description: David Fincher's movie deliciously fulfills the expectations set by Gillian Flynn's ice-in-its-veins novel of a troubled marriage; both book and movie are dark, creepy, and very good indeed.
starring: Ben Affleck, Rosamund Pike, David Fincher, Gillian Flynn

title: Dear White People
description: A smart, sexy satire about race, in which young writer/director Justin Simien announces himself as his generation's Preston Sturges.

title: Birdman
description: Alejandro Gonzalez Iñárritu’s multilayered film can be appreciated on many levels simultaneously: as a backstage-at-the-theater comedy; as a literate and literary character study; as a remarkable achievement in cinematography; as a comment on the nature of contemporary entertainment; as a showcase for one of the year’s finest ensemble casts; and as a surreal tale of a man seeking his soul.
starring: Michael Keaton, Emma Stone, Alejandro Gonzalez Iñárritu, Edward Norton, Naomi Watts

title: The Imitation Game
description: As Alan Turing, the brilliant World War II codebreaker whose life blended astonishing triumph and cruel tragedy, Benedict Cumberbatch is both self-conscious (watch the careful way Turing holds his mouth), cutting, and icy-cool, with there’s a sadness behind his characteristic smirk.

title: Selma
description: Both mesmerizing drama and timely history lesson, Ava DuVernay's depiction of a key moment in the civil rights movement stays with you long after the theater lights have been raised. With David Oyelowo in a remarkable performance as Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
starring: David Oyelowo, Tom Wilkinson, Ava DuVernay

title: Mr. Turner
description: Mike Leigh's portrait of the artist J.M.W. Turner is made up of artful dabs and splotches, and it’s often — in the manner of a great painting — mesmerizing.

title: Two Days, One Night
description: Marion Cotillard gives a devastatingly intimate performance as a Belgian factory worker struggling to save her job.
starring: Marion Cotillard, Jean-Pierre and Luc Dardenne

title: Ex Machina
description: An exquisite, baffling puzzle-box of a picture, with Alicia Vikander as a robot created by a wealthy genius scientist/entrepreneur (Oscar Isaac).
starring: Oscar Isaac, Alicia Vikander, Alex Garland

title: Far From the Madding Crowd
description: Wisely adapted by novelist David Nicholls, this Thomas Hardy drama set in 19th-century Dorset has the elegance of a Merchant-Ivory film, and yet feels utterly real.
starring: Carey Mulligan, Michael Sheen, Thomas Vinterberg

title: Mad Max: Fury Road
description: The pace is delirious, the stunts are incredible, the acting impressive -- put it all together, and you’ve got a rousing crowd-pleaser that hits on all fast-revving cylinders.
starring: Tom Hardy, Charlize Theron, George Miller

title: Love & Mercy
description: Starring John Cusack and Paul Dano, this story of the bizarre life of  Beach Boy Brian Wilson is one of the most touching — and gripping — biopics you will ever see.
starring: John Cusack, Paul Dano, Elizabeth Banks

title: Inside Out
description: Children will love this zippy, colorful Pixar adventure into an 11-year-old girl's brain; adults will find themselves unexpectedly moved, changed, and dazzled.

title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl
description: A sweet and funny film -- and the big winner at the 2015 Sundance Film Festival — about a couple of movie-mad teenagers who can’t stop making low-budget imitations of classic movies.

title: Testament of Youth
description: Based on British writer Vera Brittain's memoir about her years as a World War I nurse, this beautifully composed film vividly depicts the horrors and losses of war.

title: Amy
description: Asif Kapadia’s documentary about the short, tragic life of British retro soul singer Amy Winehouse is a heartbreaker, depicting a fresh, cheeky young woman full of life.

title: Shaun the Sheep Movie
description:
Nobody speaks in this adorable British stop-motion-animation comedy from Aardman Animation; instead, they bleat, bark, grunt, squeal, quack, coo — or, if they’re human, mutter something unintelligible. And 
yet, the storytelling’s captivating.

title: The End of the Tour
description: Essentially a Midwestern "My Dinner with Andre" set on a book tour, this film showcases a remarkable performance by Jason Segel, who seems to tie on David Foster Wallace’s trademark bandanna and disappear into the character.

title: The Diary of a Teenage Girl
description:
In this captivating debut, writer/director Marielle Heller hits exactly the right tone for a complicated balancing act: a story of a teen in 1976 San Francisco who happily enters into a sexual relationship with her mother’s boyfriend. 
(Alexander Skarsgard).

title: Learning to Drive
description: This beautifully acted tale of friendship showcases two actors finding an enchanting connection: Patricia Clarkson as a new divorcee learning how to drive for the first time; Ben Kingsley as the cabbie she hires to teach her.

title: Grandma
description: Short, tart, yet unexpectedly sweet, Paul Weitz’s dark comedy is a small-scale character study — and, because that character is played by the great Lily Tomlin, it’s mesmerizing, right up until its final frame.

title: Pawn Sacrifice
description: Edward Zwick’s tense, smart drama stars Tobey Maguire in a career-changing performance as the world’s most famous — and troubled — chess champion.

title: Goodnight Mommy
description: The bond between identical twins is the center around which the plot orbits in this moody, vastly disturbing horror picture by Austrian filmmakers Veronika Franz and Severin Fiala.

title: Sicario
description: So much of Denis Villeneuve’s disturbing drama, set in the world of law enforcement and Mexican drug cartels takes place on Emily Blunt’s face; as hardworking FBI agent Kate Macer, she’s constantly pausing, thinking, figuring things out.
starring: Emily Blunt, Benicio Del Toro, Denis Villeneuve

title: 99 Homes
description: The human cost of the 2008 economic meltdown is dramatically portrayed in this fictional story of a wicked Florida real-estate broker (an excellent Michael Shannon) who manipulates a desperate family on the verge of losing their home.

title: He Named Me Malala
description: Davis Guggenheim’s well-crafted and deeply affecting documentary digs below the iconography and the honors given to its title heroine, offering an illuminating portrait of the human being behind the image.

title: Bridge of Spies
description: Tom Hanks does some of the best work of his career in this Cold War drama about a real-life Soviet spy, directed by Steven Spielberg.
starring: Tom Hanks, Mark Rylance, Steven Spielberg

title: Steve Jobs
description: A hurricane of words pours from the screen in Danny Boyle's biopic about the software innovator, delivered with breathtaking intensity by Michael Fassbender in the title role.
starring: Michael Fassbender, Kate Winslet, Aaron Sorkin

title: Room
description: Lenny Abrahamson’s wondrous, devastating film, based on the novel by Emma Donoghue, is about a mother (Oscar-winner Brie Larson) and son imprisoned in a small room, and who ultimately must save each other.
starring: Brie Larson, Jacob Tremblay, Lenny Abrahamson

title: Spotlight
description: Tom McCarthy’s mesmerizing, Oscar-winning film is, quite simply, a story about storytelling; taking place over about a year at The Boston Globe, where a team of investigative reporters is piecing together the details of an explosive story about the Catholic Church’s cover-up of numerous predatory priests.
starring: Michael Keaton, Rachel McAdams, Mark Ruffalo, John Slattery, Tom McCarthy

title: Brooklyn
description: In John Crowley’s lovely film, about an Irish immigrant making her way in 1950s America, Saoirse Ronan (“Atonement”) provides a master class in showing, not saying, what her character is thinking; the movie unfolds on her quiet face.

title: Chi-Raq
description: The plot of "Lysistrata" gets played out in contemporary, gun-ridden Chicago, and director Spike Lee makes it burst with vitality and purpose; it has the feel of a movie made by a young man, new to the craft and consumed by a mad joy in the sheer act of filmmaking.
starring: Teyonah Parris, Wesley Snipes, Angela Bassett, Spike Lee

title: Macbeth
description: Justin Kurzel’s film is all blood and ice, a stirring, unflinching retelling of Shakespeare’s tale of a Scottish thane (Michael Fassbender), his ambitious wife (Marion Cotillard)  and a terrible deed that haunts them, leaving their hands forever stained.

title: The Big Short
description: Set in the the world of high finance as Wall Street faces a massive financial crisis, this film is all talk -- which quickly becomes weirdly fascinating, made so by the caliber of  the actors talking that talk (Christian Bale, Steve Carell, Ryan Gosling, Brad Pitt) and the supercharged intensity they bring.
starring: Christian Bale, Brad Pitt, Steve Carell, Ryan Gosling, Margot Robbie, Adam McKay

title: Carol
description: Two women meet and fall in love in 1950s New York; together, director Todd Haynes, screenwriter Phyllis Nagy, actors Cate Blanchett and Rooney Mara, cinematographer Edward Lachman and composer Carter Burwell immerse us — nearly drowning us, happily — in beauty and longing.
starring: Cate Blanchett, Rooney Mara, Todd Haynes

title: The Revenant
description: Based on a novel about an actual 19th-century incident in the days of the Western fur trade and directed with formidable skill by Oscar winner Alejandro G. Iñárritu (“Birdman”), “The Revenant” is a tale of man in a state of nature — a nature, in the words of Tennyson, “red in tooth and claw.”
starring: Leonardo DiCaprio, Tom Hardy, Alejandro G. Inarritu

title: Anomalisa
description: Charlie Kaufman (“Being John Malkovich,” “Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind”) possesses an artistic sensibility unlike any other filmmaker working today, and that sensibility informs every word and frame of “Anomalisa,” a haunting stop-motion animation tale of two lonely people.

title: Kung Fu Panda 3
description: Though “Kung Fu Panda 2” suffered from a mild case of sequelitis — overloud and overdone — the third installment is a total delight: gloriously colorful, very funny and, better yet, unexpectedly substantive and genuinely moving.

title: 45 Years
description: In this beautifully acted drama starring Charlotte Rampling and Tom Courtenay, a marriage lives and dies; we watch its agonized struggle, like a butterfly impaled on a pin.

title: The Witch
description: “The Witch,” set in Puritan New England of 1630, feels like something new in horror -- which is to say it feels like something old … authentically old.

title: Zootopia
description: This charming animated film from Disney follows a spunky bunny cop and a  cunning con-artist fox trying to crack a case of mysterious disappearances in a colorfully vibrant animals-only world.
starring: Ginnifer Goodwin, Jason Bateman, Idris Elba

title: Midnight Special
description: This sci-fi thriller, reminiscent of "The X-Files," is a long tease, artfully constructed and designed to keep the audience off balance and on edge until the very end.
starring: Michael Shannon, Joel Edgerton, Jeff Nichols

title: Everybody Wants Some !!
description: Termed by writer/director Richard Linklater ("Boyhood") as the “spiritual sequel” to “Dazed,” this story of a group of 1980s college students is sunnier and funnier by far than its predecessor.

title: L'Attesa
description: This French-language drama, from Italian filmmaker Piero Messina, is a spare, elegant tale of heartbreak — of how a story untold lets a character clutch desperately to another story, one that isn’t true.

title: The Meddler
description: Lorene Scafaria's charming film, about a mother (Susan Sarandon) who interferes in her grown daughter's life, is that rarity: The characters don’t seem like types chosen from a screenwriting manual, but like people we might know, with quirks and feelings and flaws and hearts.
starring: Susan Sarandon, Rose Byrne, J.K. Simmons

title: Love & Friendship
description: This costume drama, based on Jane Austen's "Lady Susan" and featuring Kate Beckinsale as a scheming flirt, is both self-consciously mannered and merrily playful -- a mixture that Austen herself might find just right.

title: Dark Horse
description: A group of working-class Brits breed and manage a champion racehorse in Louise Ormond's charming documentary, which could have been scripted by Hollywood -- but wasn't.

title: Weiner
description: This documentary about disgraced former congressman/serial tweeter Anthony Weiner is a fascinating portrait of a politician — a man who, it seems, doesn’t feel that he exists unless someone’s looking at him.

title: Maggie's Plan
description: Writer/director Rebecca Miller's contemporary rom-com, starring Greta Gerwig and an unexpectedly hilarious Julianne Moore, is a sweet, faintly screwball, faintly Shakespearean look at love, families and what happens when a well-made plan goes just a bit awry.
starring: Greta Gerwig, Ethan Hawke, Julianne Moore, Rebecca Miller

title: Finding Dory
description: For all its witty voices and great escapes (maybe one too many of the latter), this charming Pixar tale is ultimately a character story, and Ellen DeGeneres’ lovable, brave Dory swims right into our hearts.

title: Sunset Song
description: Terence Davies' drama, set in World War I-era rural Scotland and based on a novel by Lewis Grassic Gibbon, doesn't sentimentalize the difficult life of its heroine (lovely Agyness Deyn); but it’s breathtakingly shot, and it blooms with moments of astonishing beauty.

title: Swiss Army Man
description: Daniel Radcliffe gives the performance of a lifetime playing a flatulent corpse in this often hilarious, ultimately poignant and always bizarrely offbeat one-of-a-kind picture.

title: Hunt for the Wilderpeople
description: Laugh-out-loud funny one minute, achingly sad the next,  Taika Watiti's film takes the audience on a rollicking yet poignant journey through the New Zealand backcountry in the company of a pair of engagingly eccentric characters.

title: The Fits
description: Watching Anna Rose Holmer's debut, inspired by stories of mass hysteria, is a disorienting experience, and it’s meant to be; its eerie soundtrack suits the strange time the film depicts: that brief, vivid moment when childhood and womanhood converge.

title: Captain Fantastic
description: A compelling and original take on the well-worn territory of family ties, with Viggo Mortensen’s tough yet vulnerable performance (as a widower raising his off-the-grid brood) among his career best.

title: Life, Animated
description: Roger Ross Williams’ gentle, uplifting documentary is about storytelling: specifically, Disney-movie storytelling, and how it helped an autistic young man make sense of the world.

title: Gleason
description: There are moments, in this remarkable documentary about a former football player facing an ALS diagnosis, where it’s very hard to look at the screen; moments so devastating you wonder how this couple, and those who love them, can bear it -- but there’s also evidence of astonishing courage and miraculous love.

title: The Innocents
description: Set at a convent in wintry 1945 Warsaw and based on true incidents, Anne Fontaine’s drama is a moving study of what happens to the faithful when God’s plan suddenly seems impossible to follow.

title: Don't Think Twice
description: Mike Birbiglia's warmhearted comedy, about a close-knit improv-comedy troupe facing an uncertain future, ultimately becomes a gentle meditation on late-blooming coming-of-age.

title: Hell or High Water
description: Jeff Bridges’ voice, in David Mackenzie’s excellent contemporary Western, sounds choked with dust; his character, an aging Texas Ranger named Marcus, seems to have spent a lifetime in the kind of town where tumbleweeds just might roll down Main Street.
starring: Jeff Bridges, Chris Pine, Ben Foster

title: Our Little Sister
description: The Japanese filmmaker Hirokazu Kore-eda makes beautiful, quiet movies about families (“Nobody Knows,” “I Wish,” “Like Father Like Son”); this one focuses on a trio of 20-something siblings, living together in their family home in the seaside town of Kamakura.

title: Kubo and the Two Strings
description: Following strong work with “Coraline,” “ParaNorman” and “The Boxtrolls,”  “Kubo” takes the Oregon-based studio LAIKA’s trademark stop-motion animation to a new level, using Japanese origami techniques to create a breathtaking fantasy world.

title: Little Men
description: In its brief, intimate 85 minutes, Ira Sachs' film has much to say: about how a neighborhood, and an apartment, changes; how emotions in a family don’t always extend across generations; how money can enter a conversation and poison it, like a bad smell; and how a 13-year-old boy begins to step toward the person he might one day be.

title: Hands of Stone
description: In this boxing movie, Robert De Niro seems to come full circle: “Raging Bull” was and remains his career pinnacle, while his work here, as a trainer, ascends to near that rarefied height.

title: Southside With You
description: Being the third wheel on someone else’s first date is rarely as delightful as it is in Richard Tanne’s charming film about two 20-something lawyers -- whose names happen to be Barack Obama and Michelle Robinson -- spending some time together outside of the office in 1989 Chicago.

title: Sully
description: If Tom Hanks hadn’t existed to play the title role of heroic pilot Chesley "Sully" Sullenberger, director Clint Eastwood would have had to invent him: This is one of those cases where movie-star persona and real-life legend blend perfectly.

title: Eight Days a Week
description: Ron Howard's Beatles documentary is a thoroughly delightful, crisply edited film that takes viewers to Europe, Australia, the Far East and the U.S. where, between June 1962 and August 1966, the Fab Four played in 90 cities in 15 countries.

title: Queen of Katwe
description: Just try to resist the charms of Mira Nair’s delightful film; a triumph-of-the-human-spirit movie about a chess prodigy in the Ugandan slums that’s ultimately, well, triumphant.
starring: Lupita Nyong'o, David Oyelowo, Mira Nair

title: Certain Women
description: Kelly Reichart’s engaging, quiet film isn't so much a single narrative feature as three gently overlapping short subjects set in or near Livingston, Mont., each with an introspective woman at its center.
starring: Laura Dern, Kristen Stewart, Michelle Williams, Kelly Reichart

title: Tower
description: Using newsreel footage, rotoscoped animation and talking-head interviews, this documentary re-creates the events surrounding the 1966 Texas Tower massacre with a remarkable you-are-there immediacy.

title: The Handmaiden
description: You've probably never seen a movie quite like Park Chan-wook’s period drama gone mad; a lavishly colorful, beautifully-filmed-erotic-revenge-crime thriller set in 1930s Korea and based on Sarah Waters' novel about a Victorian-era pickpocket.

title: Moonlight
description: Barry Jenkins' lyrical, poetic Oscar winner is a three-act drama unfolding over two decades, in which a gay black man (played by three different actors) comes of age in a tough Miami neighborhood.
starring: Naomie Harris, Mahershala Ali, Janelle Monae, Barry Jenkins

title: Christine
description: As Christine Chubbuck, a troubled young reporter at a local news station in 1974 Florida, Rebecca Hall's electric performance jolts Antonio Campos's thoughtful film; you see, watching her, the terrible weight of depression.

title: Arrival
description: So much of the pleasure of Denis Villeneuve’s poignant science-fiction drama lies in watching Amy Adams figure things out; she plays a linguist recruited by the military to attempt communication with a mysterious spaceship, and we experience the movie through her perspective.

title: Loving
description: Jeff Nichols' film, about a real-life interracial couple in the 1950/60s South, is a story of heroism and the right to love, told without stirring speeches; instead, it unfolds movingly in the tiny moments between Richard (Joel Edgerton) and Mildred (Ruth Negga), two people who have, quite simply, found a home in each other.
starring: Ruth Negga, Joel Edgerton, Jeff Nichols

title: Moana
description: The greatest strength of this Disney musical adventure, about a Polynesian princess on an epic quest, is the verve in which the filmmakers move the action along and the sheer joyousness evident in every aspect of their storytelling.

title: Manchester by the Sea
description: Written and directed by Kenneth Lonergan, and starring Casey Affleck in an Oscar-winning performance, this New England drama is a movie of astonishing honesty,  an exploration of the kind of grief that causes a man to disappear even as he’s standing in front of us.
starring: Casey Affleck, Kyle Chandler, Michelle Williams, Kenneth Lonergan

title: La La Land
description: Damien Chazelle's dreamy musical, in which an aspiring actress (Oscar winner Emma Stone) and a jazz pianist (Ryan Gosling) fall in love in a Technicolor Los Angeles, is a valentine to cinema, splashed with primary colors and velvety L.A. sunsets and wistful close-ups of beautiful faces.
starring: Ryan Gosling, Emma Stone, Damien Chazelle

title: Jackie
description: Pablo Lorrain's sort-of-biopic is a strange movie — it feels, like Natalie Portman’s haunting Jackie, like it might shatter if dropped — and yet it's mesmerizing; a familiar story told from an entirely different angle.
starring: Natalie Portman, Greta Gerwig, Peter Sarsgaard

title: Lion
description: Garth Davis' heart-tugging movie has one of those plot lines that feels like a Hollywood screenplay — tiny child, separated from his family, searches for them decades later -- except it actually happened. It's mesmerizingly told, particularly its vivid and nearly wordless first half.

title: Fences
description: This wise, electric adaptation of August Wilson's Pulitzer Prize-winning play, set in 1950s Pittsburgh, “Fences” wraps you and whirls you in a heady cyclone of words; Denzel Washington and Viola Davis (who won an Oscar for this role) give performances for the ages.
